Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Computational Cybersecurity in Compromised Environments (C3E) is a community of interest that has annually gathered, since its inception in 2009, to address some of the most arduous challenges of cybersecurity. Through these annual workshops and planning meetings, C3E provides a forum for multi-disciplinary researchers from the top academic, industry, and government to discuss innovative approaches to the cybersecurity challenges facing our Nation. This year the challenge will be related to cyber deterrence.

This travel grant will support an estimated ten travelers to the 2015 C3E workshops. The results of these workshops will be widely disseminated in the open literature, including on the CPS-VO web portal. Additionally, this workshop and its challenge problems will create excellent opportunity for students to engage with leaders in the field in the context of unsolved problems.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this project was to support the NSF/ODNI-sponsored 2015 Computational Cybersecurity in Compromised Environments (C3E) One-Day, Mid-Year Meeting was held on June 19, 2015 at the Software Engineering Institute in the Ballston community of Arlington, Virginia.

This project specifically funded Vanderbilt University's Institute for Software Integrated Systems' (VU-ISIS) ability to provide travel support to selected  participants participating in this meeting. VU-ISIS provided these travel recipients with a travel guidance policy document and expense worksheet created by VU-ISIS in advance of the meeting. This documents contained important information about Vanderbilt University's travel reimbursement policies and other requirements for non-Vanderbilt personnel. Post-meeting, VU-ISIS staff processed documents for payment.

Data collected is stored on the CPS VO private program committee site as historical artifats for this activity. This information can only be accessed by authenticated users with regisered CPS VO accounts. The C3E website can be found at http://cps-vo.org/node/3847.

the 2015 C3E One-Day, Mid-Year Meeting is designed to advance scientific knowledge by exploring the theme of attribution (the identity or location of an attacker or an attacker's intermdiary, [Wheeler and Larsen, IDA, Paper P-3792], as a central element of deterrance and prevention against various forms of cyberattacks and explotations from four vantage points: types, timing, investigators, and jurisdiction. This meeting also investigated the refining of existing methods and the exploration of new concepts to help advance knowledge to counter strategic conflicts that arise in cyber security.

The 2015 C3E One-Day, Mid-Year Meeting builds on teh approaches and discoveries of previous C3E Meetings since the launcing of this meetings series in 2009. A major underpinning of this and previous C3E meetings is to bring together cyber security experts with other societal members, including non-cybersecurity experts and leading scientists, to engage in a dialogure to identify and exchange ideas, thoughts, and approaches from non-cyber fields of research which could have applicability in the cyber security domain.

 


Last Modified: 11/22/2016
Modified by: Frankie King
